content:
The Act titled "College Research Education and Teacher Excellence (CREATE) Opportunity Act of 2012" makes the research credit permanent and includes other modifications. The Act "College Research Education and Teacher Excellence (CREATE) Opportunity Act of 2012" makes the research credit permanent by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It also increases the percentage of contract research expenses paid to colleges and universities. The Act "CREATE Opportunity Act of 2012" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to make the research credit permanent. It also modifies the inclusion of social sciences in qualified research to focus on arts and humanities. The amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2011. TITLE II--YEAR-ROUND PELL GRANTS

SEC. 201. AMENDMENTS. Section 401(b) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow students at junior or community colleges to receive up to two Federal Pell Grants in a single award year to accelerate their progress towards a degree or certificate. Students must be enrolled at least half-time for more than one academic year in a program of instruction. Students at junior or community colleges can receive more than one Federal Pell Grant in a single award year to accelerate their progress towards a degree or certificate. The total amount of Federal Pell Grants awarded to a student for the award year may exceed the maximum basic grant level specified in the appropriations Act. Section 401(b)(2)(A)(ii) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to change a specific paragraph reference. The amendments made by section 201 will be effective starting from the 2013-2014 award year. Additionally, there are amendments to the TEACH Grant Program. Section 420N of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to address the repayment for inability to complete service obligations for TEACH Grants recipients. If a recipient fails to fulfill their service obligation, a portion of the grant received will be treated as a loan and collected from the recipient. If a TEACH Grants recipient fails to meet their service obligation, the grant amount received will be treated as a Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loan and must be repaid with interest, based on the extent of non-compliance. The amendments made by section 301 will apply to TEACH grants awarded from the academic year 2013-2014 onwards.
